title: Penalized Precision Matrix Estimation in grasps
text: Consider following setting: Gaussian graphical model (GGM) assumption: data \(X_{n \times d}\) consists independent identically distributed samples \(X_1, \dots, X_n \sim N_d(\mu,\Sigma)\). Disjoint group structure: \(d\) variables can partitioned disjoint groups. Goal: Estimate precision matrix \(\Omega = \Sigma^{-1} = (\omega_{ij})_{d \times d}\).

title: Penalized Precision Matrix Estimation in grasps
text: \[\begin{gather} \hat{\Omega}(\lambda,\alpha,\gamma) = {\arg\min}_{\Omega \succ 0} \left\{ -\log\det(\Omega) + \text{tr}(S\Omega) + \lambda P_{\alpha,\gamma}(\Omega) \right\}, \\[10pt] P_{\alpha,\gamma}(\Omega) = \alpha P^\text{idv}_\gamma(\Omega) + (1-\alpha) P^\text{grp}_\gamma(\Omega), \\[10pt] P^\text{idv}_\gamma(\Omega) = \sum_{,j} p_\gamma(\vert\omega_{ij}\vert), \\[5pt] P^\text{grp}_\gamma(\Omega) = \sum_{g,g^\prime} p_\gamma(\Vert\Omega_{gg^\prime}\Vert_F). \end{gather}\] : \(S = n^{-1} \sum_{=1}^n (X_i-\bar{X})(X_i-\bar{X})^\top\) empirical covariance matrix. \(\lambda \geq 0\) global regularization parameter controlling overall shrinkage. \(\alpha \[0,1]\) mixing parameter controlling balance element-wise block-wise penalties. \(\gamma\) additional parameter controlling curvature effective degree nonconvexity penalty. \(P_{\alpha,\gamma}(\Omega)\) generic bi-level penalty template can incorporate convex non-convex regularizers preserving intrinsic group structure among variables. \(P^\text{idv}_\gamma(\Omega)\) element-wise individual penalty component. \(P^\text{grp}_\gamma(\Omega)\) block-wise group penalty component. \(p_\gamma(\cdot)\) penalty kernel parameterized \(\gamma\). \(\Omega_{gg^\prime}\) submatrix \(\Omega\) rows group \(g\) columns group \(g^\prime\). Frobenius norm \(\Vert\Omega\Vert_F\) defined \(\Vert\Omega\Vert_F = (\sum_{,j} \vert\omega_{ij}\vert^2)^{1/2} = [\text{tr}(\Omega^\top\Omega)]^{1/2}\). Note: regularization parameter \(\lambda\) acts scale factor entire penalty term \(\lambda P_{\alpha,\gamma}(\Omega)\). penalty kernel \(p_\gamma(\cdot)\) shape function governs fundamental characteristics regularization. Lasso: Least absolute shrinkage selection operator (Tibshirani 1996; Friedman, Hastie, Tibshirani 2008) \[\lambda p(\omega_{ij}) = \lambda\vert\omega_{ij}\vert.\] Adaptive lasso (Zou 2006; Fan, Feng, Wu 2009) \[ \lambda p_\gamma(\omega_{ij}) = \lambda\frac{\vert\omega_{ij}\vert}{v_{ij}}, \] \(V = (v_{ij})_{d \times d} = (\vert\tilde{\omega}_{ij}\vert^\gamma)_{d \times d}\) matrix adaptive weights, \(\tilde{\omega}_{ij}\) initial estimate obtained using penalty = "lasso". Atan: Arctangent type penalty (Wang Zhu 2016) \[ \lambda p_\gamma(\omega_{ij}) = \lambda(\gamma+\frac{2}{\pi}) \arctan\left(\frac{\vert\omega_{ij}\vert}{\gamma}\right), \quad \gamma > 0. \] Exp: Exponential type penalty (Wang, Fan, Zhu 2018) \[ \lambda p_\gamma(\omega_{ij}) = \lambda\left[1-\exp\left(-\frac{\vert\omega_{ij}\vert}{\gamma}\right)\right], \quad \gamma > 0. \] Lq (Frank Friedman 1993; Fu 1998; Fan Li 2001) \[ \lambda p_\gamma(\omega_{ij}) = \lambda\vert\omega_{ij}\vert^\gamma, \quad 0 < \gamma < 1. \] LSP: Log-sum penalty (Candès, Wakin, Boyd 2008) \[ \lambda p_\gamma(\omega_{ij}) = \lambda\log\left(1+\frac{\vert\omega_{ij}\vert}{\gamma}\right), \quad \gamma > 0. \] MCP: Minimax concave penalty (Zhang 2010) \[ \lambda p_\gamma(\omega_{ij}) = \begin{cases} \lambda\vert\omega_{ij}\vert - \dfrac{\omega_{ij}^2}{2\gamma}, & \text{} \vert\omega_{ij}\vert \leq \gamma\lambda, \\ \dfrac{1}{2}\gamma\lambda^2, & \text{} \vert\omega_{ij}\vert > \gamma\lambda. \end{cases} \quad \gamma > 1. \] SCAD: Smoothly clipped absolute deviation (Fan Li 2001; Fan, Feng, Wu 2009) \[ \lambda p_\gamma(\omega_{ij}) = \begin{cases} \lambda\vert\omega_{ij}\vert & \text{} \vert\omega_{ij}\vert \leq \lambda, \\ \dfrac{2\gamma\lambda\vert\omega_{ij}\vert-\omega_{ij}^2-\lambda^2}{2(\gamma-1)} & \text{} \lambda < \vert\omega_{ij}\vert < \gamma\lambda, \\ \dfrac{\lambda^2(\gamma+1)}{2} & \text{} \vert\omega_{ij}\vert \geq \gamma\lambda. \end{cases} \quad \gamma > 2. \] Note: Lasso, convex, additional parameter \(\gamma\) required, penalty kernel \(p_\gamma(\cdot)\) simplifies \(p(\cdot)\). MCP SCAD, \(\lambda\) plays dual role: global regularization parameter, also implicitly contained within kernel \(p_\gamma(\cdot)\). Figure 1 illustrates comparison various penalty functions \(\lambda p(\omega)\) evaluated range \(\omega\) values. main panel (right) provides wider view penalty functions’ behavior larger \(\vert\omega\vert\), inset panel (left) magnifies region near zero \([-1, 1]\).  Figure 1: Illustrative penalty functions. Figure 2 displays derivative function \(p^\prime(\omega)\) associated range penalty types. Lasso exhibits constant derivative, corresponding uniform shrinkage. MCP SCAD, derivatives piecewise: initially equal Lasso derivative, decreasing intermediate region, eventually dropping zero, indicating large \(\vert\omega\vert\) receive shrinkage. non-convex penalties show smoothly diminishing derivatives \(\vert\omega\vert\) increases, reflecting tendency shrink small \(\vert\omega\vert\) strongly exerting little shrinkage large ones.  Figure 2: Illustrative penalty derivatives.
code: library(grasps) ## for penalty computation library(ggplot2) ## for visualization  penalties <- c("atan", "exp", "lasso", "lq", "lsp", "mcp", "scad")  pen_df <- compute_penalty(seq(-4, 4, by = 0.01), penalties, lambda = 1) plot(pen_df, xlim = c(-1, 1), ylim = c(0, 1), zoom.size = 1) +   guides(color = guide_legend(nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE)) deriv_df <- compute_derivative(seq(0, 4, by = 0.01), penalties, lambda = 1) plot(deriv_df) +   scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 1.5)) +   guides(color = guide_legend(nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE))

text: goal grasps provide collection statistical methods incorporate element-wise group-wise penalties estimate precision matrix, making user-friendly useful researchers practitioners. \[\hat{\Omega}(\lambda,\alpha,\gamma) = {\arg\min}_{\Omega \succ 0} \{ -\log\det(\Omega) + \text{tr}(S\Omega) + \lambda P_{\alpha,\gamma}(\Omega) \},\] \[P_{\alpha,\gamma}(\Omega) = \alpha P^\text{idv}_\gamma(\Omega) + (1-\alpha) P^\text{grp}_\gamma(\Omega),\] \[P^\text{idv}_\gamma(\Omega) = \sum_{,j} p_\gamma(\vert\omega_{ij}\vert),\] \[P^\text{grp}_\gamma(\Omega) = \sum_{g,g^\prime} p_\gamma(\Vert\Omega_{gg^\prime}\Vert_F).\] details, see vignette Penalized Precision Matrix Estimation grasps.

title: grasps
text: package grasps provides functions estimate precision matrices using following penalties: See vignette Penalized Precision Matrix Estimation grasps details.

code: gen_prec_sbm(   d,   block.sizes = NULL,   K = 3,   prob.mat = NULL,   within.prob = 0.25,   between.prob = 0.05,   weight.mat = NULL,   weight.dists = list("gamma", "unif"),   weight.paras = list(c(shape = 100, rate = 10), c(min = 0, max = 5)),   cond.target = 100 )

title: Block-Structured Precision Matrix based on SBM — gen_prec_sbm
text: d integer specifying number variables (dimensions). block.sizes integer vector (default = NULL) specifying size group. NULL, \(d\) variables divided evenly possible across \(K\) groups. K integer (default = 3) specifying number groups. Ignored block.sizes provided; K <- length(block.sizes). prob.mat \(K \times K\) symmetric matrix (default = NULL) specifying Bernoulli rates. Element \((, j)\) gives probability creating edge vertices groups \(\) \(j\). NULL, matrix within.prob diagonal .prob -diagonal used. within.prob numeric value [0, 1] (default = 0.25) specifying probability creating edge vertices within group. argument used prob.mat = NULL. .prob numeric value [0, 1] (default = 0.05) specifying probability creating edge vertices different groups. argument used prob.mat = NULL. weight.mat \(d \times d\) symmetric matrix (default = NULL) specifying edge weights. NULL, weights generated block-wise according weight.dists weight.paras. weight.dists list (default = list("gamma", "unif")) specifying sampling distribution block weights. length determines distributions assigned: length = 1: specification blocks. length = 2: First within-group blocks, second -group blocks. length = \(K + K(K-1)/2\): Full specification block. first \(K\) elements correspond within-group blocks indices \(1, \dots, K\), remaining \(K(K-1)/2\) elements correspond -group blocks ordered \((1,2)\), \((1,3)\), \((1,4)\), ..., \((1,K)\), \((2,3)\), ..., \((K-1,K)\). element weight.dists can : user-supplied sampling function. function must accept argument n specifying number samples. character string specifying distribution family. Accepted distributions (base R samplers parentheses) include: "beta": Beta distribution (rbeta) "cauchy": Cauchy distribution (rcauchy). "chisq": Chi-squared distribution (rchisq). "exp": Exponential distribution (rexp). "f": F distribution (rf). "gamma": Gamma distribution (rgamma). "lnorm": Log normal distribution (rlnorm). "norm": Normal distribution (rnorm). "t": Student's t distribution (rt). "unif": Uniform distribution (runif). "weibull": Weibull distribution (rweibull). weight.paras list (default = list(c(shape = 100, rate = 10), c(min = 0, max = 5))) specifying parameters associated weight.dists. must follow length rules weight.dists. element named vector list suitable corresponding sampler. cond.target numeric value > 1 (default = 100) specifying target condition number precision matrix. necessary, diagonal shift applied ensure positive definiteness numerical stability.

title: Block-Structured Precision Matrix based on SBM — gen_prec_sbm
text: object S3 class "gen_prec_sbm" containing following components: Omega precision matrix SBM block structure. Sigma covariance matrix, .e., inverse Omega. sparsity Proportion zero entries Omega. membership integer vector specifying group membership.

title: Block-Structured Precision Matrix based on SBM — gen_prec_sbm
text: Edge sampling. Within- -group edges sampled independently according Bernoulli distributions specified prob.mat, within.prob .prob prob.mat supplied. Weight sampling. Conditional adjacency structure, edge weights sampled block-wise samplers specified weight.dists weight.paras. length weight.dists (weight.paras) determines weight distributions assigned: length = 1: specification blocks. length = 2: first within-group blocks, second -group blocks. length = \(K + K(K-1)/2\): Full specification block. Block indexing. order blocks : Within-group blocks: Indices \(1, \dots, K\). -group blocks: \(K(K-1)/2\) blocks order \((1,2)\), \((1,3)\), \((1,4)\), ..., \((1,K)\), \((2,3)\), ..., \((K-1,K)\). Positive definiteness. weighted adjacency matrix symmetrized used precision matrix \(\Omega_0\). Since arbitrary block-structured weights may positive definite, diagonal adjustment applied control eigenvalue spectrum. Specifically, let \(\lambda_{\max}\) \(\lambda_{\min}\) denote largest smallest eigenvalues matrix. non-negative numeric value \(\tau\) added diagonal $$ \left\{ \begin{array}{l} \dfrac{\lambda_{\max}(\Omega_0 + \tau )}{\lambda_{\min}(\Omega_0 + \tau )} \leq \texttt{cond.target} \\[1em] \lambda_{\min}(\Omega_0 + \tau ) > 0 \\[.5em] \tau \geq 0 \end{array} \right. $$ ensures positive definiteness guarantees condition number exceed cond.target, providing numerical stability even high-dimensional settings.

title: Performance Measures for Precision Matrix Estimation — performance
text: Let \(\Omega_{d \times d}\) \(\hat{\Omega}_{d \times d}\) reference (true) estimated precision matrices, respectively, \(\Sigma = \Omega^{-1}\) corresponding covariance matrix. Edges defined nonzero -diagonal entries upper triangle precision matrices. Sparsity treated structural summary, remaining measures grouped loss-based measures, raw confusion-matrix counts, classification-based (structure-recovery) measures. "sparsity": Sparsity computed proportion zero entries among -diagonal elements upper triangle \(\hat{\Omega}\). Loss-based measures: "Frobenius": Frobenius (Hilbert-Schmidt) norm loss \(= \Vert \Omega - \hat{\Omega} \Vert_F\). "KL": Kullback-Leibler divergence \(= \mathrm{tr}(\Sigma \hat{\Omega}) - \log\det(\Sigma \hat{\Omega}) - d\). "quadratic": Quadratic norm loss \(= \Vert \Sigma \hat{\Omega} - I_d \Vert_F^2\). "spectral": Spectral (operator) norm loss \(= \Vert \Omega - \hat{\Omega} \Vert_{2,2} = e_1\), \(e_1^2\) largest eigenvalue \((\Omega - \hat{\Omega})^2\). Confusion-matrix counts: "TP": True positive \(=\) number edges \(\Omega\) \(\hat{\Omega}\). "TN": True negative \(=\) number edges neither \(\Omega\) \(\hat{\Omega}\). "FP": False positive \(=\) number edges \(\hat{\Omega}\) \(\Omega\). "FN": False negative \(=\) number edges \(\Omega\) \(\hat{\Omega}\). Classification-based (structure-recovery) measures: "TPR": True positive rate (TPR), recall, sensitivity \(= \mathrm{TP} / (\mathrm{TP} + \mathrm{FN})\). "FPR": False positive rate (FPR) \(= \mathrm{FP} / (\mathrm{FP} + \mathrm{TN})\). "F1": \(F_1\) score \(= 2\,\mathrm{TP} / (2\,\mathrm{TP} + \mathrm{FN} + \mathrm{FP})\) "MCC": Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC) \(= (\mathrm{TP}\times\mathrm{TN} - \mathrm{FP}\times\mathrm{FN}) / \sqrt{(\mathrm{TP}+\mathrm{FP})(\mathrm{TP}+\mathrm{FN}) (\mathrm{TN}+\mathrm{FP})(\mathrm{TN}+\mathrm{FN})}\) following table summarizes confusion matrix related rates:

title: Groupwise Block-Banded Sparsifier — sparsify_block_banded
code: library(grasps)  ## reproducibility for everything set.seed(1234)  ## precision matrix estimation X <- matrix(rnorm(200), 10, 20) membership <- c(rep(1,5), rep(2,5), rep(3,4), rep(4,6)) est <- grasps(X, membership = membership, penalty = "lasso", crit = "BIC")  ## default: keep blocks within ±1 of each group res1 <- sparsify_block_banded(est$hatOmega, membership, neighbor.range = 1) plot(res1)   ## wider band: keep blocks within ±2 of each group res2 <- sparsify_block_banded(est$hatOmega, membership, neighbor.range = 2) plot(res2)   ## special case: block-diagonal matrix res3 <- sparsify_block_banded(est$hatOmega, membership, neighbor.range = 0) plot(res3)
